content:
I like using Obsidian app for authoring long form content.
For thinking, I prefer Logseq

content: Digital gardens are often work-in-progress sites where people share their interests, hobbies, work or even thinking - publicly.

content:
Hugo is the static site generator I’m using to build this site.
It is fed my Logseq exported graph.
summary:

title: Hugo

content:
Logseq is the first note-taking app that worked for my chaotic mind.
I have tried Obsidian, however the longer form pages v/s blocks as the primary unit of knowledge keeps me firmly with Logseq.
summary:
Logseq is the first note-taking app that worked for my chaotic mind.
I have tried Obsidian, however the longer form pages v/s blocks as the primary unit of knowledge keeps me firmly with Logseq.
title: Logseq

content:
This is a test.
A tiny test. What if I published a Logseq graph as my personal website?
A digital garden! Let’s see what makes more sense - a Hugo theme or the whole Logseq web-app.
The Hugo theme is very appealing because it is not bandwidth hungry.
And it works without JavaScript!
Okay, with the exception of one concern - I’m not sure I like the latest-notes approach, can be quite confusing for a new visitor.
summary:
This is a test.
A tiny test. What if I published a Logseq graph as my personal website?
A digital garden! Let’s see what makes more sense - a Hugo theme or the whole Logseq web-app.
The Hugo theme is very appealing because it is not bandwidth hungry.
And it works without JavaScript!
Okay, with the exception of one concern - I’m not sure I like the latest-notes approach, can be quite confusing for a new visitor.
title: Oct 8th, 2022
